posts.name: Steven Carmain
posts.cooked:
In WpiLib, is there a way to run a mechanism with one shot control for exactly 87ms (or some other exact timing requirement)?

I understand it won’t be exactly right since we aren’t an RTOS, but I would like control faster than 20ms.  I think the wait command won’t work, as it runs at the command scheduler rate.  The WpiLib timer doesn’t have an interrupt when finished.

Any suggestions on how to do 1 shot control like this?  Use a notifier?  Spin a thread with Java’s timer.sleep()?

posts.name: Tinnittin
posts.cooked: This sounds like an XY Problem . What are you trying to accomplish by controlling something to exactly 87ms and where 80ms or 100ms wouldn’t work?

posts.name: Steven Carmain
posts.cooked:
So, for 98% percent of FRC problems, I agree, 20ms control is ok for most of the problems.  Although when you use hardware PID support, that runs at 1ms, so I don’t think my request is unreasonable.

Problem statement: We have an analog pneumatic cylinder powering our shooter.  You put air in one side, it goes up, then you trap the air in it and it holds it spot.  (a couple check valves will vent air on system release to comply with R813A)

Right now, we use a bang-bang controller, basically turn on the solenoid until you reach the angle requested (actually a couple degrees before because of inertia).  This is causing problems, as we can’t get much better than about 3-4* of control.  You can even watch it wave at us trying to aim… https://youtu.be/oQ7fzUgCELM?si=cqAuj5gHElzpDZpk&t=44 On blue at center of stage.

So we thought about changing to a feed-forward control, where we would basically calculate how long we would have to fire it (based on ramp rate, sensor delay, activation time, etc) before we stop the solenoid.  You can’t PID the solenoid, as there is no analog control, and you can’t PWM it either.  This is the only solution I can think of that might work.  Maybe 20ms timing is ok, but you can see it bounce a lot to try and find the target with feedback control.

(I think it adjust from 30-55* in about 1 second, and our flow restrictors are basically as far as they go in.  You don’t want to lower pressure really, as this mechanism is a balance of force already, and you remove the flow restrictors and the mechanism just drops).

posts.name: usbcd36
posts.cooked:
Yes, there is functionality for more granular timing:

TimedRobot ’s addPeriodic() method allows one to run custom methods at a rate faster than the default TimedRobot periodic update rate (20 ms). Previously, teams had to make a Notifier to run feedba...

There’s more to be done (measuring the elapsed time, performing the actual control), but you could use this to get, say, 1ms update rates.

link_counts.title: Scheduling Functions at Custom Frequencies — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
usbcd36:

There’s more to be done (measuring the elapsed time, performing the actual control), but you could use this to get, say, 1ms update rates.

That’s not going to be possible in Java.  At these frequencies, OS scheduling jitter alone can be an issue, let alone GC pauses.  It might be in C++, but fundamentally OS jitter (and CAN bus variable latency) becomes a limiter here.  I think 971 (using a bunch of custom C++ code and very careful management of threading priorities, etc) got there for their “kicker” a couple years ago, but I don’t think they used CAN .

Steven_Carmain:

Right now, we use a bang-bang controller, basically turn on the solenoid until you reach the angle requested (actually a couple degrees before because of inertia).

Would Solenoid.setPulseDuration() fit the bill with some inner/outer loop work?  That allows pretty precise control of each solenoid pulse.  The precise pulse duration would be controlled by the PCM /PH, with an outer control loop telling it how long to pulse (the PH allows control within 1 ms).  It would require a lot of tuning because most solenoid valves have a minimum pulse duration needed to even open the valve, but I assume you already know that.

posts.name: Steven Carmain
posts.cooked:
It might work, it’s definitely something we can look at!

Only problem might be we use the double solenoid class to run this.  Maybe if we break up the double solenoid into individual solenoids, that might work easier.

Or I think a notifier would work too.  I actually like the pulse duration approach more.

And as I saw your edits, I think I need the feed forward to have the following timings:

Open valve

Move time

Stop time

Equilibrium time

I would sum them up (maybe more), and then send a single pulse duration command to actually do the move.  The harder part is to calculate what the time pulse should be, not commanding it I think.
